Also fixed up the CSS arrow width.  It is at a 45° angle so must be multiplied by cos(PI/4)
Just realised this might break the Jasmine specs.

Still accurate even if it doesn't look that explicit! ;)

well that's a weird one

I've had soooo much trouble with FF on windows when creating arrows.

I've had bugs like antialiasing on one side only making it much fatter than it should be :D
I can also add that I tried playing around with some `z-index` but was unsuccessful.

I don't think this is actual solvable. I'd love to get suggestions though. I believe whats happening is that iOS is doing subpixel rendering.

Perhaps I could target it with media queries so zooming wouldn't be needed.
sweet!
I guess I won't be using cssarrowsplease as testing ground for webperformance optimizations anymore then.
Is there a LESS version of just cssarrowplease anywhere? The HackerNews thread listed by @barnabyc won't load for me (not sure if it's still available).
@cdnme The HackerNews thread loaded for me: https://gist.github.com/2644661

The actual generated arrow code does work with IE8 and is not CSS3 (:before and :after are part of CSS2). 

To get the website (again, the generated arrow code works) to work in IE8 is a bigger issue as I am dynamically changing a stylesheet depending on the settings the user enter, and sadly IE8 does not treat a <style> tag the same way as other browsers, which makes this a little troublesome

So you mean it can work in IE8 but its just your website does not work? 

I changed your code to not use :before and :after, and just add in the HTML and target it with a class, then that does work in IE8. I have not had to dynamically change it like on your website, but would have thought some Javascript would be able to handle that?
See pull request #32 for a fix for the top position only.
Sweet! Could you add a test to that and i'll merge it in :) Thanks!

Hi,

I added some tests for the hexToRGB function and a test for the _arrowCSS border color.
I also updated the hexToRGB function to check the input color and to support 3 char hex colors (ex: #888).
Thanks!
Sorry for taking so long to get back to you on this. Could you rebase and add tests for this?
Are you happy for the fix to only apply to the top position?

@bensummers Im ok to apply just that if it works. However it seems like a hack? The problem exists because zooming does subpixel rendering on the ipad.

To merge this, I need some specs to exercise this code.
Add specs here: https://github.com/hojberg/cssarrowplease/tree/master/public/js/spec 
and see the results by running https://github.com/hojberg/cssarrowplease/blob/master/public/js/spec_runner.html in any old browser.

This is a great idea! The shadow however is not part of the generated code - perhaps it should be.

I'll look into it, thanks!

Sorry I have been unresponsive.

hmm this is odd, looking into that. Domain is paid, so shouldn't be happening.

Tony meyer

I had some A records pointing to some old nodejitsu ip's that they deprecated and finally removed a few weeks ago.
Looking good - thanks!
It wouldn't work on IE8 then.
What's the point of the rgba() version anyway? Zero opacity with any color is the same as transparent, is it not?

As I said in the comments within the CSS above, some browsers need the 'transparent' version (IE8-) and other browsers specifically need the rgba() version (FF PC). So the reason for having the rgba() version is to support that particular browser.
Indeed :)
I'll add this shortly.

This is indeed to handle clicking, hovering and touching through the arrow.

If for any reason you'd not want this behavior, modify the outputted CSS - If people often disable it, I could add a toggle in the configuration.

IE does not support pointer-events at all right now (http://caniuse.com/#feat=pointer-events).
Good point. I'll add a toggle.

_through_ the arrow? As in elements behind the arrow would receive pointer events instead of the arrow? If that's true, it would indeed make sense to include it.

Btw, I do believe IE10 on win8 would support pointer-events, but only with -ms- prefix. I'm not sure though, since I don't have a win8 with touchscreen to test on.

Loosely related, can you (@thesheep) point to a resource that describes or demonstrates the bug in FF? I'm quite interested to see what it's about. Because, I've personally never seen any issues with it, to be perfectly honest.

@thany Um, no sorry. I tested it on a page I was building at the time, but don't have access to it anymore. If you've tried the code above and you don't have a problem on FF for Windows, then perhaps they have plugged the issue with a new version of FF? Should be fairly easy to test.

I did some more research on this in the mean time, and the only thing I could find is a thin darkened border appearing on the slanted sides of the "triangle", but only when hardware acceleration is disabled in Firefox options. Of course we shouldn't assume hardware acceleration is always enabled.

I also read it can be worked around by using `border-style: outset` instead of the usual solid. But that produces a slighty weird result as well, on all IE's. So I guess rgba() is the better option after all.

At least it's been cleared up so far :)

Just checked, IE10 _does_ support pointer events. it registers MSPointerUp, MSPointerMove and MSPointerDown. Not the standards events, but they are indeed implemented. And indeed, `-ms-pointer-events` does do something. So caniuse.com in this case is wrong. This can happen from time to time, of course.
sweeeeeeeet!

How to add transparent colour inside arrow?
@varunsood this is unrelated to this commit, but you can just replace the `border-bottom-color`/`border-top-color`/`border-left-color`/`border-right-color` to the transparent rgba color
I haven't been able to see any issues with zooming in chrome at least. Either with pinch zoom or cmd + '+'

Chrome doesn't zoom the font. At least not on desktop, and not always. And sometimes automagically. Firefox doesn't either, but it can be toggled. Either way, your visitor's OS may be set to large fonts.
Defo would like this!

Yeah this sounds like a good idea.

I think the 0 just hides 3/4 of the border then the top-colour overrides. Actually I tried to change the settings but couldn't get alpha to work on the arrow at all.
@QuantumInformation yep, but could be accomplished by just `transparent`. Sucks that alpha doesn't work :( I vaguely remember that now as well.
Sorry what do you mean by transparent?
@QuantumInformation the "color" `transparent` can be used for backgrounds and borders
